title: OpenBuilds® OPEN RAIL™ Open Source Linear Bearing System

description.text:
The OpenRail™ system was created by Mark and Trish Carew of http://www.OpenBuilds.com UPDATE V9.Zip added to include VSlot® Extrusion Framing System
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:69333 OpenBuilds™ Parts are now available in many easy to use and share formats!
Including STEP / IGES / SolidWorks / SketchUp Please see the OpenBuilds Parts Resource section here to grab'em. http://www.openbuilds.com/resources/categories/openbuilds-parts.5/
Thank you and all the best with your builds!
Mark Carew Example builds
OpenBuilds® Open Rail is a new Open Source Universal Linear Rail System designed to be used in conjunction with various sizes of readily available T-Slot aluminum extrusions.
The Open Rail system will be made of 6061-T5 Aluminum with Black Hard Coat Anodized, Type III, which means we will have the ability to use both metal v wheels for heavy wear light duty applications and plastic v wheels for quiet light duty applications. This, along with Open Rail's unique ability to adapt to many different aluminum extrusions configurations makes it the most versatile linear rail system available today. The linear V guides have been around for a long time. The problem in the past has been mounting them to existing extrusions. This can be difficult and unconventional. Open Rail was designed to make installation a breeze (easily installs with included screws and t-nuts) and completely customizable unique to each machine. NOTE: The pictures included are quick renderings to give a few examples of what could be possible. They do not represent complete machines...Yet! :) Thank you
OpenBuilds Team

OPENRAIL™
Where can I get it?
http://www.openbuildspartstore.com Check out the link for videos and more info:
http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/openrail/openrail-open-source-linear-bearing-system Features
A few key features that make the OpenRail attractive to the Maker in us all, is the ability to span the t-slot with pre-drilled holes and use t-nuts for easy mounting to t-slot extrusion. Open Rail will be hard coat anodized (harder than tool steel) http://www.matweb.com/reference/anodize.aspx. The Open Rail system is versatile in that it has the ability to overlap and create a single double v rail extrusion system as well as fit onto other extrusion configurations. Open
But most of all, what we feel is the most important and exciting aspect of the Open Rail system is the ability to bring this to the open source world so that others can build from it. Our intention is to share this idea completely with everyone who wants to create with it. When the drawings are final they will be open to anyone who wants to create the Open Rail. There are no commercial limitations so small maker businesses are free to sell these extrusions to help further seed this system to others. We are working to have dies made overseas so that the guys over there will not have to pay large shipping to have an inexpensive and customizable linear rail system for making their next cool projects. UPDATE - NEW VERSION OF OPENRAIL HAS BEEN UPLOADED! V7 Just uploaded a new ZIP that contains lots of different formats (Thanks to George and Scott)
including an updated version of the SketchUp model which has been cleaned up a little and now contains a new extrusion we did not know was compatible 8020s series 10 profile! Download the Zip and Check out the SketchUp for more. *MK - http://www.mknorthamerica.com/store/series-25/profiles.html
(Check sketchUp to which ones will work) *Bosch - http://www13.boschrexroth-us.com/Framing_Shop/Product/Default.aspx?category=10101
(Check sketchUp to which ones will work, there may be more of these out there. Just added a few we found) *8020 - http://8020.net/T-Slot-5.asp
(10 series profiles (fractional) - 20 series profiles (metric) - 25 series profile (metric) Check sketchUp to which ones will work) *Misumi - http://www.misumiusa.com/CategoryImages/AluminumExtrusions/Extrusion-Browser.html
(Check sketchUp to which ones will work) *OpenBeam - http://blog.openbeamusa.com/
(Works with smaller screws with OpenRail stacked double. Take a look at the SketchUp) *MakerBeam - http://www.makerbeam.eu/
(Works with smaller screws with OpenRail stacked double. Take a look at the SketchUp) This is a short list of some of the extrusion profiles OpenRail is compatible with (Check the SketchUp for sizing with the profiles you want to use) We are sure there are more If you find them please let us know in the comments.

comments.author: Nigei22

comments.text:
Jason, I would not try to use a 3D printed version of the OpenRail™ system for a CNC router as it just will not really stand up the forces. Your best bet would be to grab some inexpensive OpenRail from the OpenBuilds Part Store and then you can mount it anyway you like. This way you are sure to have a precise rail system that will not break or wear down on you.
You can find OpenRail here: http://openbuildspartstore.com/openrail-linear-rail/
Hope this helps, and all the best with your Builds!
Mark

comments.text: We just wanted to do a quick update of Version 1 (rough) drawings for a couple of the OpenRail V Wheel Designs.  In addition to the standard Delrin V Wheels, these will also be available.  You can see that we have a break on the outside as well as the inside which will allow us to use these wheels on interior v tracks for future design considerations.  There is still much work and testing to be done but the prospect of having the choice between metal and plastic v wheels is awesome!

title: 8mm Threaded rod spool mount V-Slot extrusion

description.text:
I like to use the spool hubs that can be found HERE and I needed a way to mount this on the D-Bot. This is a simple mounting block that will require two nuts to secure the 8mm threaded rod.

UPDATE - V2 is now uploaded. After printing the part, I realized the nut opening was not large enough. I am printing another right now to test, but I will be uploading the files as I need to change them.

This is the final version

OK, V3.1 is the final version. It has a little more reinforcement as it is just a little bit larger. Just for those that are printing in materials that have more give than the PETG I used to print mine with.

I bought a Kreg cabinet handle jig and it worked great for my 4" handles, but my drawers had a wider spread so I made this enlarged version of the Jig.

It uses the angle and drill bushings from the purchased jig, so the new version is not functional by itself. You need to buy the Kreg jig and transfer the parts.

The design has notches set at 4" and 7.5", you may need to add more notches to suit your need.

https://www.amazon.com/Kreg-Company-KHI-PULL-Cabinet-Hardware/dp/B01JQ74J5E/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1503012412&sr=8-1&keywords=kreg+handle+jig

title: Custom Grip for Baikal MP-657 Air Pistol

description.text:
The Baikal MP-657 is an affordable, CO2-powered target air pistol, with a rather atrocious factory grip. I know that everybody's hands are different, but the stock grip really doesn't look like it was made for a human. Luckily, I've got a 3D printer and Blender.

The grip was made to fit my (medium-sized) hand, and it could be that it won't fit yours very well. If you have some Blender skills, I've included the original .blend file, with the subdivision surface model. The inside shape that mates with the grip frame, is a separate object, combined with the outside shape using a Boolean operator. This should make it easy to adapt the grip to your own hand, since you don't run the risk of messing up the fit to the frame.

author: HatCigarNeckbeard

description.text:
Have a Roosh? Have a Runcam micro? This is for you.

This is the best way to mount the Runcam Micro on the FloRotors Roosh frame. It uses the honeycomb pattern to lock in the tpu mount. The two plates hug it just enough to squeeze the camera nicely while still allowing you to tighten or loosen the camera to adjust it with the screws.

Uber light weight. Super squishy for vibration dampening. Amazingly simple and fast to print.

My Original Model based on Yars Revenge video game for the Atari 2600. One of my favorites back in the day. I made this model a few years back based on the Yars from the Comic included with the game. Including Atari Symbol to hold him up with the Qotile Base as... well a base lol.

This will make a great gift for those who are fans of classic retro games.

Little tips for assembling: I used a Hot glue gun to fix parts into place. It really hold Great what with the glue and heat from it fixing parts.

Antenna was included with the model however I couldn't get it to print (My Printer is a .4mm) So I opted to take two little thin pieces of wire and with a little help from a lighter I lit one end and just stuck them into the post I made on top of the head.

Printer:

Da Vinci Jr 1.0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4mm

Infill:

40%

Great Retro Game Project Recommended Items (Other than a 3d Printer) Small Hot Glue Gun (To fix parts into place. This is more for the Claws) Small Wire (For Antenna at the Top of the head) Primer (I used Black primer) Model Paints (Red, Yellow, Silver, Blue, Light Blue, Bronze, White for highlights, Black for touch up) A Pair of Nail Clippers (To clip stubborn structured supports)

This spinner can be balanced by turning three carriage bolts in and out of the three arms. If the spinner is held vertical, it can be balanced such that none of the bolts will gravitate toward the lowest position. The o-rings put more squeeze on the bolts (they could fly out at high speed), but they also make the spinner nicer to grip in your hand. I also chose to go with a standard hex nut and bolt for the thumb pieces just to keep with the mechanical look.

The second version is more robust and keeps a tighter grip on the screws.

Extra Materials:

  • (1x) 608 skateboard or fidget spinner bearing
  • (1x) 5/16-18 x ½ long Hex Bolt (for thumb piece)
  • (1x) 5/16-18 Hex Nut (for thumb piece)
  • (3x) 5/16-18 x 1 long Carriage Bolts
  • (3x) #204 O-rings (3/8 ID x 5/8 OD)

title: DIY Drop Capsule Slide Model Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Who doesn't love a good water slide? I've been quite interested in drop capsule slides lately. You know, the ones that go 3. 2. 1. Launch! and the floor drops out from underneath you and plummet down the slide? Why not a mini model. Sure. How about a WORKING model? Great! How about a model that you can make your own layout? Awesome!
So that's what I've done!
You are the designer!
Simply print the (coming soon) drop capsule assembly (pod, door, base, drop floor, trigger pin, and platform) and then print the tower pieces (base connectors and pylons, as many as you need for whatever height you want) and then print as few or as many slide pieces as you want to create your own layout! (you'll also want to print a splashdown so you can connect a pump) Once assembled, customize to your liking, connect a small water pump and off you go! Take a dive into a simple 75deg drop or create one with lots of turns and drops! Check the image above for the basic features and a nice moderate layout idea and suggest some below!
So step on in and 3. 2. 1. PRINT!

UPDATE LOG

8.29.17 Don't use the older splashdown part. It's cumbersome and defective. A new one will be posted soon.

I had to fix the resulting model to be able to be printed in plastic using meshmixer and meshlab

In geometry, the truncated octahedron is an Archimedean solid. It has 14 faces (8 regular hexagonal and 6 square), 36 edges, and 24 vertices. Since each of its faces has point symmetry the truncated octahedron is a zonohedron. It is also the Goldberg polyhedron GIV(1,1), containing square and hexagonal faces. Like the cube, it can tessellate (or "pack") 3-dimensional space, as a permutohedron.

Its dual polyhedron is the tetrakis hexahedron.

If you want to support me, consider getting one of my lamps on Etsy: http://www.geolume.etsy.com

print_settings.Notes:: Press is one print. Cut apart center disc (webs between center disc and ring) and sand smooth outside of center disc, and inner surface of press, where the meat goes. A dremmel (if you have or can borrow one) makes smoothing edges easy. Press meat into press into a dish shape; thinner in the center and even with the outer edge of the ring. If meat is pressed in even across press, the burger will become rounded while cooking, and look like a meatball.

This is the plastic insert inside the rubber outer wrapper of the stock radio in a newer Cooper Mini Car.

Outer rubber from original goes over this insert and the original metal insert goes on the inside.

I found the original had too large of an inner diameter, even with the instruction to use the metal insert from the original knob.

My 2005 Mini radio has a knob with a 4.8 mm D-shaft, so I have adjusted the design for that size. Metal insert is no longer required.

Why purchase a reasonably priced perfect replacement for your broken DC25 End Cap Assembly when you can print this working but slightly imperfect one for (almost) free? Good question, right?

This slightly imperfect End Cap Assembly includes a screw that seems to be optional due to minor size discrepancies making the part a rather snug fit. Optional parts are the best parts, I always say.

Note that you will have to apply some force to push the brush widget's bearing into the slot. Be sure it is in all the way, but not so all the way such that the brush doesn't turn freely.

Tested via largish home vacuuming. It works. SHIP IT.

Painstakingly (and mostly accurately) reverse engineered from the genuine (but alas broken) part with a ruler and digital calipers. Source files are in OnShape here.

Feel free to fix my mistakes and add a remix!

title: Part Cooling duct mod for Prusa i3 Mk2

description.text:
On some of my more complex 3d print designs I have found that the stock Prusa part cooling duct that blows only from the front is not enough. Steep over hangs and details on the back side of the build plate seem to suffer. Since Ultimaker uses two fans blowing from opposite sides I thought I would see what I could do for the Prusa. The space is so limited that the only thing I could come up with is a modified version the stock part cooling duct. My version not only blows on the print from the front but also from the side. And this seems to help on the more complex prints.
https://youtu.be/qhA5XOsIb3c

Prusa

comments.text: I'm having issues with curling overhang on a file that has overhangs from every angles. I will print this one and give you my impression. I'm pretty sure it will improve the result since Prusa Research themselves did use a similar solution with their new MK3 :D
comments.author: gaellafond

comments.text:
Peter seems to have a better design:
https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/improvements-f14/improved-fan-shroud-nozzle-t5263-s10.html#p40796
comments.author: gaellafond

comments.text: how is this working out for you so far? I love the concept.
comments.author: Drazen

comments.text: It has no negative effects that I can see. I have not printed the same files from the past that had problems do to the limited part cooling fan of the factory design. I stay very busy with new projects and its hard to find the time to go back and print a complex part just to see if it has improved the quality of the print. But so far all the new part files look great, so no reason not to try it. I still would love to find a way to get a second blower on there, either front and back or side to side. If a person wanted to use a air compressor instead of blower fans then small tubes could be run just about any place as part cooling devices. Probably would be quitter also and I do have a large air compressor out in the shop where I work but I was looking for a solution that would work for every one and this was what I came up with.

author: Print3DLLC

description.text:
I needed a piece to hold filter material for the upcoming eclipse. These were designed for 53mm diameter Leupold 10x42 binoculars. They are a nice press fit on those. They should fit anything that has the same size objective lens. They also allow the use of the normal lens caps to protect the delicate filters.

If you do use this design, please make sure you're using safe, ISO-rated filter material. Any shortcuts could cause blindness. You are magnifying the sun with binoculars and can blind yourself in milliseconds if your filter material is sub-par.

author: oktkas

description.text:
This design was made using Meshmixer and the program "Structure Synth" which you can download here:
http://structuresynth.sourceforge.net/download.php

To print, I scaled the model up by a factor of 10.

The fractal uses the code below to make 25 iterations; each cube at scale .95 is rotated along every axis by 10 degrees

R1
set maxdepth 25
rule R1 {
{ x 0.5 rx 10 ry 10 rz 10 s 0.95 } R1
{ s 4} box
}

Inspired by the Maker's Muse video.

description.text: This is my first design and build.  This fan baffle attaches to the side rail and blocks the power supply fan from blowing on the bottom of the build plate and also keeps scraps from falling into the power supply.
Just print and attached to the side rail with M5-10 screws and T nuts. Use Post Install T nuts so you don't need to disassemble. http://store.makerstoolworks.com/hardware/t-slot-nuts-post-install/

print_settings.Notes:: This print works best around 100%, but slightly larger or small will work too. The overall length should be about 168mm. The support is built-in. I believe that most Infill amounts will work, but I have only used 20%.

description.text:
The Handy Bottle Opener is inspired by the Osprey hand.
We HOPE that you are inspired to give others a hand. Our aim is to raise awareness about organizations that are seeking to connect with and provide support to all that need a prosthesis. Please spread the word, we are hoping to connect with and support all in need.

Hands On Prosthetic Engineering, HOPE, is a student organization dedicated to providing free prosthetic hands to all children through 3D creation. We are an all-volunteer organization with a 501c Non-profit that provides funding for both our free services and the research and development to further it. Our Non-profit provide students the opportunity to serve the smallest parts of their world with the biggest reach possible. 100% of tips will be donated to HOPE, and may be claimed. Visit www.hopeuofsc.org for more information or to contribute. Follow us on:
www.facebook.com/hopeuofsc/
www.twitter.com/@HOPEuofsc/
www.instagram.com/hopeuofsc/

The e-NABLE community is an amazing group of individuals from all over the world who are using their 3D printers to create free 3D printed hands and arms for those in need of an upper limb assistive device. Please take a moment to visit www.enablingthefuture.org for more information or to contribute.
Thank you to Alderhand and e-Nable.

You can also reach us at:
Hands On Prosthetic Engineering HOPE
1225 Laurel Street
Suite # 418
Columbia, SC 29201

Officer Phone: (803)-228-9088
Office Email:
[email protected]

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Notes:

This print works best around 100%, but slightly larger or small will work too. The overall length should be about 168mm. The support is built-in. I believe that most Infill amounts will work, but I have only used 20%.

Remove support

Remove built-in support by snapping the support columns in the bottle cap opening.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0ijT5XKDi5M
The RoboFamily consists of the laser-cut AlphaBot and his children both printed with the Makerbot

The Girl Robot is based on the Protobot[ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18264 ] and the Boy Robot of the Tribot "Scout" [ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13042 ]. To personalise the smaller robots it is possible to add servo-holders in the front and a component which can be attached to an ultrasonic sensor. This extension allows the robots to turn the sensor in different directions. In addition our family is able to communicate with each other via XBee and the kids can identify the direction of the adult. Each family member ist able to show emotions like anger or confusion. The robots were created in the context of a collegiate project at the University of Bremen. Components: Small ones (quantity for one):
  • Printed parts
  • 1 Arduino Uno
  • 1 Lithium-ionic-9V-battery (rechargeable), normal 9V batterie works as well, but do not last very long
  • 3 Servos (two need to be "hacked")
  • 1 Ball for the Ball-Bearing
  • 1 Ultrasonic sensor
  • 1 XBee-Module and 1 Pololu IR-Beacon for Communication
    • The Alphabot is designed for 3,6mm plywood. For the Wheels we used LEGO-tyres and two 12V gear motors.
  • Printed/cutted parts
  • 1 Arduino Mega
  • 1 LCD-Display
  • 2 LEGO-tyres
  • 2 gear motors
  • 1Ultrasonic sensor
  • 2 IR-sensors
  • Various LEDs
  • 1 Speaker
  • XBee-Module and Pololu IR-Beacons for Communication
    • Have fun with your new family =) Roboting-Team from FabLab Bremen

description.text: This is a trainer, not a weapon. This is inspired by the SOCP Dagget by Benchmade. It is a skeletonized dagger that is light weight and easy to use. You do not need to put it down if you were to draw your airsoft pistol.
If you want this can be vapor smoothed.
This was inspired by the SOCP Dagger by Benchmade. My friend had one and it is beautiful and fgelt great in my hand. I used Fusion 360 to model this.

yKnow, the turny thing you turn and it opens the window?

I couldnt find one so I made one. The handle has 12 teeth, v2 has 15.5mm diameter, v3 has slightly smaller diameter(?) and pointier teeth (it was jumping over teeth on the window)

I measured and copied a temporary handle i had. We had 3 windows and one handle. Fixed!

I had to use v2 and v3 for different windows, but they all work great. Sure beats the crappy temporary one that came with them, especially since we only had one handle for all three windows.

The three fills are solid, the other is v1, probably wont work. It just imitates the hollow nature of the original temporary one.

Printed fine with a 0.4mm nozzle at 0.3mm layers. The white filament hides the layers really well, so you cant even see them at 0.3mm.

title: Caliburn Mega XL
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
8/19/17 - Sorry folks, like all WIP updates are to be expected. The ram failed at the 4-40 screw hole due to the added stress from the o-rings grabbing on to the barrel too tight. I redesigned it to have a thicker wall by the screw holes and made the o-ring area smaller to loosen the grip on the barrel. I will also put some epoxy between the bolt and jam to solidify it into one piece instead of putting the stress on the 4-40 screw hole. New file is CM_Ram v2.

This is a Caliburn for Nerf Mega and BuzzBee XL darts. Most of the parts and hardware stay the same but the magazine is designed from scratch.

Thanks to Captainslug for a great design on the Caliburn blaster.

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

25 and 100%

Notes:

All parts keep the infill percentages from the original files.

Magazine assembly

The magazine has 5 parts. There is an upper body, lower body, sleeve, floor plate and follower. A spring will be needed to complete the magazine. I reshaped the spring from a 20 round Action Warriors Buzzbee magazine for mine. The sleeve holds the upper and lower halves together with 16ga or 1/16" weld rod pins. The floor plate and lower body are connected by drilling holes and running in some screws. I used some PC case screws I had laying around.

Fit and finish

I left some tolerances a little tight and some sanding will be needed to get them just right. Notably the barrel with the muzzle and receiver (mag well) and the bolt into the ram.

The magazine and tweaking the design

I do not own any mega or XL dart magazines so I decided to design one. It holds 8 rounds but needs the ram back to insert.

I strengthened the front of the receiver because the barrel diameter left too little material and the prints failed when the barrel was pressed in.

I also put witness holes to easily see if your running out of darts. The transparent barrel gives you a good look at your loaded dart. The front of the receiver has indents for nylon lock nuts. The back requires regular nuts to allow the magazine to clear. Umbrella is about 65 to 70 feet away.

Upscale an alternatives

Barrel - McMaster-Car part# 2044T45
O-rings - P14 (13.8 x 2.4mm) x2
Tube spacers - Carbon Express Wolverine 55-70 lb Draw Arrow, 30" at Walmart
Threaded rod - 15" for the two upper rods

title: Anet A8 - Extruder fan and heatsink easy removal

description.text:
Hello, I modified the original project in order to fit with my printer. First of all I have a filament guide in the place where the original project would be screwed, so I modified the project to screw it in the line down.

Secondly I have a chain that is attached on the right hand side, that is creating problems with the original adaptor so I have reduced it.

If you use a 3x20 screw with nut for the moving part, it should be strong enough to avoid the heatsink to move from its position. In case you have problems I have also created a version with a pin that you can put in, to lock everything.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I have used:

3x20 (2) screws to hold the motor to the extruder
3x20 (2) screws to hold the fan to the heatsink with some washers
3x20 (2) screws to hold the fan to the pla cover
3x20 (1) with 2 nuts screw for the moving part
4x30 (2) with 2 nuts to hold the fixed part to the extruder (better if you use 4x14 without nuts, but I didn't have)

description.text:
[EDIT] I put this back as a work in progress because I found that the connection between the nub and the stick didn't hold well with just hot glue with repeated use. I'll want to update it by changing the connection.

Customize stick height and stick radius to make it longer or thicker for your needs. If you do, PLEASE share a make and let me see how it turned out!!

This is a Spinning Axle apparently - according to this Indiegogo: https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/dawson-precision-spinning-axle#/

It wont cost you $170 though.

I also added fillet versions that I edited in 123D to make a little nicer edges on them.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

No supports necessary for the cap if you have good bridging.

If you want to save lots of time, you can also lay the stick 90deg on its side.

Print two caps, one stick, and two nubs. Put a 608ZZ bearing in each cap. Push the nubs into the bearings. Apply a teeny bit of hot glue to the little nub's square and push it into the stick.

I needed to sand off the little layer start blobs everywhere.

Spin!
I made several iterations to get the tolerances right. This is my first design using OpenSCAD and it's really fun! I like manipulating shapes using functions rather than visual drags and such.
This is just a basic mount for any webcam.  I'm using a Logitech C920, but any camera with a standard 1/4" tripod mount screw should work.

Just print and attached to the side rail with M5-10 screws and T nuts. Use Post Install T nuts so you don't need to disassemble. http://store.makerstoolworks.com/hardware/t-slot-nuts-post-install/ For the camera, a standard 1/4-20 screw or bolt should be all you need. I used a slightly longer screw with a nut on it so it is easier to hand tighten.

title: Nerf AR15 Stock remix plus shoulder pad

description.text:
I decided to remix but cutting out the center to open up and lighten the appearance of this nerf stock. I am currently printing it now, so I am unable to comment on the rear fitment.

I also designed a shoulder pad that can be glued after it is printed to reduce the amount of slippage...because you know these Nerf rifles have that crazy kick.

I am uploading the Sketchup and STL fils as usual.

I believe ChaserDK stated you'll need an M5 nut. But the design was so spot on for me that it fits very snugly onto the blaster.

Have fun and Happy Modding

I just loaded two more pics.

  1. Fresh off the printer without me cleaning out the Nut, screw filler
  2. everything cleaned and the rear tread foot glued on.

print_settings.Notes:: Print in a flexible filament (TPU, NinjaFlex, etc). I printed with 100% infil and no supports.

description.text:
My kids just got the Octopus smart watch, but the band was uncomfortable because of the raised dots on the underside of it. Here's a 3d printed band that will work as a replacement for the existing band. When you remove the existing watch band, be sure to save the pins so that you can use them for this band.

You can choose between long & short versions of each half of the band. Also, the side with holes in it comes in tapered & non-tapered versions.

You'll probably have to do some rotating of parts to orient them correctly on your bed. Sorry about that.

PLEASE test your watch band on your child to make sure it stays on how you'd like and fits properly. My printer probably works slightly different than yours, so make sure all the parts fit well after you print them on your printer.

title: Hendrix College Technology Services Logo Nick Nack

description.text:
This is an interlocking Hendrix College Technology Services Logo, meant to be built in three separate passes (black, white, and orange).  
The project closely follows the Hendrix Graphic Identity standards, but in its current state needs either "1876" or "Hendrix" in the shield to be 100% compliant. Therefore, this should not be considered an "official" wordmark representation.

You can check out how I designed this, here: http://davidjhinson.wordpress.com/2014/02/13/technology-services-nick-nack-a-3d-project/ The project is meant to be built in three (3) passes: Black Filament with the Black Pieces file, White Filament with the White Pieces File, and Orange Filament with the Orange Pieces File. When all passes are done, the completed pieces should snuggly fit together into a finished logo design. Just a Heads Up - The pieces will fit... but you may have to gently tap them using a mallet. The tolerance is tight.

title: Velleman K8200 3D printer - LED ring light

description.text:
This time I have added a light around the extruder.
I bought a tent light - it contains 2 rings with white 5mm LEDs.
I have created a circular holder for the rings, 2 holding arms and I've reused my previously designed clips (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221362).
For the PWM driver I used Atmega328P microcontroller with an Arduino bootloader.
I have soldered it on a single layer protoboard with designed base that can be mounted on the mainboard mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:230616). More details, the source code, schematic, part list can be found on my blog: http://ljwinkler.blogspot.com/2014/02/led-ring-light-for-velleman-k8200-3d.html Cheers,
LJ

title: Hornady Lock n load AP Auto Progessive Press Case Feeder.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you use this, enjoy it, and feel like you'd like to show your appreciation, feel free to fund my filament costs ;-)
https://www.paypal.me/JSondag

It's come to my attention that a lot of people who want this do not have a 3D printer. Please PM me, and I can print this out for you, if you don't know someone with a printer.

Videos:
https://youtu.be/_sRv3OksBgA
https://youtu.be/BAcAf7Q6n5o

Assembly
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UaE40fDb8JM
This video was not made by me, but I was given permission to use it.
I would deviate from this instruction in the following ways

Pre-assemble the parts and put glue in the dovetails, and around the mount bracket wherever the mount bracket and top body come into contact.

That top screw the holds the spring in for the slider, I use an M4 screw and thread it into the plastic rather than dropping in a screw and relying on gravity.

The stabilizer is first attached slightly loose on to the pattern, once the whole assembly is attached the press, it's then slid down to contact the table. The holes are then located, pilot drilled and screwed to the bench. The screw is then tightened to the pattern.

I use a bit stiffer spring in the turntable part, and tighten it far enough that rotation is just still barely possible so it doesn't flop around.﻿

This is a 3D printable case feeder for the Hornady Lock n load Auto-Progressive reloading press. This one does not cost $300+, and doesn't have any automatic motorized feeding that costs the big bucks. Instead it's modeled off the Lee feeder mechanism with four tubes that can be rotated into position once empty.

To assemble and attach this, you will need the following:
2x 1/4"-20 x 3/4" long bolts.
2X 1/4" washers
1X M4 x 20mm machine screw
1X M4 x 8mm machine screw
1X 23/64" x 1-3/8" (9mm x 35mm) compression spring
1X 1/4" x 4" (M6 x 100mm) full thread hex bolt, or all thread.
3X 1/4" or M6 nuts. (4 nuts are needed if using all thread for the above bolt)
1X M3 x 20mm machine screw
1X 7/32" or 1/4" x ~3/4" (6mm x 20mm) compression spring
4X + extra. 5/8" (16mm) OD tubing. Thin wall preferred to allow larger cases.
Optional: Lee case feeder tubing ~9/16" (14.5mm) OD tubing

Sources:
M4 screws
https://smile.amazon.com/Glarks-280-Pieces-Phillips-Stainless-Assortment/dp/B01G0LBEAW/ref=sr_1_5?s=hi&ie=UTF8&qid=1503033486&sr=1-5&keywords=m4+screw

Springs
https://smile.amazon.com/CSLU-Tool-Assorted-Small-Springs-Assortment/dp/B071R18Z6X/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1503031869&sr=8-1-spons&keywords=assorted+springs&psc=1

5/8 Tubing
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B001IJKELC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Lee Tubing
https://smile.amazon.com/Lee-Precision-Case-Feeder-Tubes/dp/B000N8JWEO/ref=sr_1_1?s=pet-supplies&ie=UTF8&qid=1503032722&sr=8-1&keywords=lee+feed+tubes

The 5/8 tubing is used at the top of the case feeder to hold cases. It is used above the top slider to keep the cases from falling over when the slider moves back. This piece should be long enough that your tallest case can sit inside the top slider, and clear the top holder, and have this tube go from up inside the top case holder, to just a couple millimeters above the top slider. The exposed part of the tube should have the half facing the hole in the slider removed to allow to case to be moved forward out of it. This tube is also used below the top slider to allow smaller cases such as 9mm, .40, .45, etc. to fall down to the ram plate without falling over (40mm length). It's also used to line the inside of the hole of the top slider, though this is probably not requiered.

The lee tubing is a slip fit within the 5/8" thin wall tube listed above, and allows a simple sleeve to slide inside the top turret which will allow it to be set to a height that works for 7mm Rem Mag, .308, etc. and switch to a height that will work for 9mm, .40, and .45, and another that will work for in between cases like .38/.357 mag very simply

The model is assembled with dovetails, which fit together tighly. Depending on the material you use, your extrusion multiplier, or you printer, you may need to sand or file the dove tails. I reccomend a drop or two of CA glue on the part of the upper box piece that wraps around the mounting bracket. After you've put them together, as you may not have time to get the dove tails tight if you put glue in first. This probably isn't nessesary, but will add rigidity

There is some play in the mounting to allow you to get it aligned just right, but I find that holding it all the way up and to the right side of your press when tightening the bolt works well. The nose that fits into the lower slider is adjustable in and out to match your case size, and to fine tune to your press, and to if you want it to require pressing forward to seat a primer to fully push in the case. It's locked into it's position with an M4x8mm screw.

The top case holder's rotating piece should be attached to the stationary piece by putting a small compression spring inside it, and screwing an M3 or equivalent screw into the undersized hole in the stationary piece through the spring, and the hole in the rotating piece. This will allow it to rotate, and be indexed on the four bumps. So you can switch tubes when one is empty.

The top slider should be slid onto the main body from the front, and a 9mm x 35mm compression spring should be pushed into the back. A 20mm long M4 screw is then screwed into the hole on the top of the top slider while the slider is held back against it's stop, and the spring is slightly compressed. (easier than it sounds)

This should work for any case up to at least a 7mm mag. I can load 7mm mag on it, and then simply slide in an insert tube, and load 9mm (after switching over dies, shell plate, etc.) without any other adjustment to the feeder. For .458 socom I simply take a piece of the 16mm tubing, that's split down the middle and wrap around the top down tube just above the lip of the case.

The pictures should make this all clear, but feel free to ask questions.

Feel free to modify using the Fusion 360 files, though they are a mess, as I just started using this tool, and this is my first project with it, and I didn't RTFM.

Happy Reloading!

Update 8/25/2017:
Added Case Collator
Added stabilizer

Case collator insert attaches at the top of the feed tubes.
There is a version for rifle cases that I designed for .308. Will likely work for other cases.
There is also a version for pistol cases. The pistol version needs a washer that prevents them from going down the tube backwards. A model for a washer is included which works for 9mm and .40 S&W, possible others. Another version is included that SHOULD work for .45 ACP. I don't load .45 so I haven't tested it. Don't dump the cases in right over the holes. This can cause upside down cases if one happens to hit the hole just right upside down.

I've also included a file for a stabilizing part that attaches on the pattern piece and screws to your bench. I found that I needed this when the tubes were full of cases and had the collator on top, as it wobbles, and flexes the whole feeder. I've not tested this yet, so please consider it experimental. I've updated the pattern to have a screw hole in case you want to screw the stabilizer onto it, but I'll probably glue it.

Update 9/1/2017:
Added 5mm of upward travel on mount bracket.
Decreased Lower Slider Nose height by 3mm
Increased stabilizer height by 7mm and made the screw hole a 7mm long slot.

Update 10/5/2017:
Added parts with a 0.2mm tolerance on the dovetails. Parametric in the design file.
Added an enhanced version of the stabilizer.
Added collator, and tube holder parts for lee tubes.
Uploaded new design file.

Update 11/2/2017:
Added chamfers, and fillets to improve fitment and function
Sliding rails, and dovetails have 0.3mm fillets to combat corner swell.
Sliding rail on upper body has looser tolerance to allow easier sliding without sanding.

Update 11/19/2017:
Changed lower slider to lock dovetail into place with a M4x8 screw for easier adjustment.
Looser tolerances on lower slider, in both dovetail, and sliding slot.
Made holes larger in block washers so screws will slip though the holes.
Added a collator dish with a 0.2mm tolerance on the central hole for a better fit on some printers.

Update 3/27/2018:
Added a brace that helps support the pattern when the foot can't be mounted to a bench. This was designed by another user, and sent to me. I've edited it to have some tolerance for a better fit, added chamfers, and thickened part of it slightly from his original design. It installs between the pattern, and mount bracket.

comments.text: JSondag - You have created a very innovative design here!  I had an acquaintance print one out for my LNL and after reviewing the images and videos, I am still a bit fuzzy on where the springs, screws and bolts are supposed to go.  Your instructions call for two springs, but in the comments you only discuss what appears to be the larger spring that goes on the upper bullet feeding shuttle.  Where does the second one go?  My guess is the lower shuttle that pushes the case onto the LNL itself, but I am not 100% sure.  Though there are not that many screws, its not clear where you want them to go.  Same with the bolts.  I really don't want to ruin it by improper assembly.
comments.author: martinontheroad

comments.text:
The other small spring goes on the top part that the tubes fit into. you place it into the hole on the top, and put an M3 screw in through it, and screw it down to the part that attaches to the main body of the press with the M6 or 1/4" bolt. The spring allows the part to rotate, while still allowing it to rise up over the four bumps that index it. Screw it down just far enough that it can still lift against the spring to turn.
.30-06 is smaller than 7mm Magnum, by a decent margin, and should be fine.
comments.author: martinontheroad

comments.text: Thanks, this makes perfect sense.  I was 'way off in thinking it was pushing the case onto the LNL plate.  I am busy accumulating the proper screws and springs. title: Raspberry Pi Zero Stem Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The much improved Version 2 is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2516525

This is a case for the Raspberry Pi Zero or Zero W with the "Stem" by zerostem.io - a PCB shim that turns it into a dongle.

We bought the Zero Stem from Pimoroni who are awesome.

The other case we tried was oversized, printed badly and actually fell apart due to not being designed properly - so we made this one!

The case was created from scratch in SketchUp to fit the Zero Stem as closely as possible.

There's two versions of the case, and two versions of the lid too!

One case has the Pi Zero / Zero W fully enclosed, the other allows access to the HDMI and USB ports - both have just enough access to the micro SD card for a pair of tweezers or small pliers so you can go ahead and glue the lid on.

The USB port for power is intentionally enclosed as it's redundant with the Zero Stem and should not be used.

One version of the lid has access to the header if you have it soldered in and the other does not.
The SketchUp file is also included if you want to remix it.

print_settings.Notes:: The Arm, Worm Gear and Worm Drive may require supports depending on your printer quality.

description.text:
This is a phone stand with elevation adjustment capabilities which is done by a worm drive.

All fasteners used are M4 and some parts may need to be joined together with superglue.
The Worm Drive and Gear must be aligned in a specific orientation.
For Assembly instructions please refer to the exploded drawing.

Note:If you are having trouble printing the worm drive as a whole part, you can try printing the alternative Worm Drive 1 and 2 with the key first, then superglue the 3 parts together. You may need to use a file or knife to refine the part edges to get them to fit together depending on your print quality.

Printer:

Velleman Vertex

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

40%

Notes:

The Arm, Worm Gear and Worm Drive may require supports depending on your printer quality.

Some file work may be required for the Worm Drive to smoothen and refine the shape. The M4 Nut that goes into the Worm Drive must be superglued in place and the screw used to connect the Knob and the Worm Drive cannot be shorter than 60mm. When assembling the Arm to the Worm Gear the screw could threaded in place via the side of the bracket.

Please refer to the exploded drawing for assembly details.

comments.text: I'm having problems marrying 10 and 13 together. The knob would either turn independently or would tighten down and wouldn't move.
comments.author: _ToXIc_

comments.text:
Hi ToXIc
Thank you for trying out my design
In order for knob and the worm drive to remain rigid when being rotated you must ensure that the M4 nut is superglued to the worm drive and the M4 screw connecting the parts together to be no shorter than 60mm. Another thing to note is that when installing the knob with the screw in it is to ensure that it is tightened before marrying it to the worm drive.
comments.author: _ToXIc_

comments.text:
Great job but I can't print the worm drive. Whether standing or lying down. :-(
Is it possible to have two halve part of it ? (sorry for my english)
comments.author: Gregem

comments.text:
Hi Gregem
Thank you for taking an interest in my design.
The worm drive is the hardest part to print and it may take a couple of tries to get it right. For me I printed the part upright with full support everywhere and a brim with a 0.2 resolution, after the print I used a small file to smooth out the surface. I have not tried halving the part but if you still run into problems I will try to upload a 2 part print for the worm drive.
comments.author: Gregem

comments.text: Thank you for your quick answer ^^
comments.author: LarkysPrints

comments.text: Hi Gregem

description.text: An original design, which uses photographic slides for "lenses." The point here is not to use the glasses as slide viewers, but to allow the general shade, hue and pattern of a slide determine the tint of your glasses.

Print each temple and the main body, along with two of the pins. These pins fit into the hinges on either end of the glasses. 
I have included the SketchUp file, as it may be necessary to adjust the sizing of the glasses (I have a rather large head, and nose, and have tailored the sizing here to fit my noggin.)

title: Guitar Amp Marshall Key Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Bill of materials

  • (4x) 6.35 female jack socket (AliExpress)
  • (4x) 6.35 male jack socket (AliExpress)
  • (4x) Rings / chain for keychain : I ordered the wrong products on Ali (too big...)

Parts

  • bottom : small rectangular piece with 4 holes for the female sockets
  • top : large rectangular part
  • marshall: Marshall logo : Print at 150%
  • case : Main part of this project, the "box"
  • support : wall mount

Print Settings

See the Print Settings category below, some parts need supports and more infill.

Assembly instructions

  • Print, sand and paint the parts
  • Loose the "leg" on the female sockets, in order to easily plug/unplug the jack
  • Screw the female socket on bottom
  • Glue the marshall logo to top
  • Slide bottom into case (you can put some glue on it, to be sure)
  • Glue top into case
  • Fix support on your wall with 2 screws
  • Assemble case on support

Other

If you have any ideas, question or suggestions, don't hesitate to let a comment !

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Case piece

  • Needs support (Touching Buildplate)

Marshall logo

  • Designed too small. Print it at 150%.

Support piece

  • Needs more infill (50-60%) because the legs are quite fragiles.

Inspired on "Marshall Jack Rack" by pluginzkeychains
Designed with Solidworks

title: Resistor, capacitance, IC, electronic components storage drawers

description.text:
A box with 5 drawers. Each drawers has a support for small paper label.
Print many box you want, and put together with glue.

You can put many electronic components : resistors, capacitors, IC, diode, transistor...

If you have a large 3D printer, you can modify OpenScad file for print many box as the same time. You can also enlarge drawer with OpenScad file.

Casier avec 5 tiroirs. Chaque tiroir possède un emplacement pour une petite étiquette avec la valeur de la résistance.
Imprimer autant de casier que vous souhaitez, et coller les assemble avec par exemple de la colle chaude.

Vous pouvez ranger autant de composants que vous souhaitez : résistances, condensateurs, transistors, circuit intégré...

Si vous avez une imprimante 3D avec une plus grande zone d'impression, vous pouvez modifier le fichier openscad pour imprimer plusieurs casiers en même temps.
Vous pouvez également modifier le fichier openscad, pour changer la taille des tiroirs par exemple.

title: Hydroelectric System (Turbine, Generator Housing, Enclosure) for NEMA 11 Stepper Motor

description.text:
My intention was to make a vertical hydroelectric turbine/generator system which could drive a standard stepper motor without the need for additional bearings etc. The hydroelectric system would be placed in an area where there is a reasonable, constant flow of water but where there is not a high head of water pressure. A requirement is that the water enters the turbine in a uniform manner, hitting all the blades at the same time in a more/less equal quantity so as not to unevenly load the shaft and bearings inside the motor (this will need to be taken into consideration when placing this in a real-world situation). I took the prop by dreyfusduke and inserted a cavity within it to take a NEMA 11 stepper motor along with the housing I designed. I also added a skirt at the bottom of the prop to allow water to pass over the motor mounting bracket and allow the electronics to clear the spinning turbine core. Care will need to be taken to ensure the motor electronics and wiring are out of reach of the moving water, though I think they will be fine with the present design.

M2.5 bolts to attach stepper motor to housing. M3 bolts to attach housing to enclosure. I'd suggest something like an XL6009 buck/boost converter to bring the voltage up to a level you need for your application. Also, this would be nice with a Nema 17 motor inside it but the problem was that the propeller already has a diameter of 150mm and the enclosure is even larger. This is coming close to the limits of most people's 3D printers. However, a Nema 17 would really make more sense as a generator. So if someone fancies modifying the design to take a Nema 17, that'd be great.

Still waiting to print and test... but as I don't have an application for it (ie. I dont have a stream in which to place it) I will probably not be printing it anytime soon. But if you do, please let me know how it goes.

description.text:
Great for mountain and geography geeks!

I plan this to be a collection of all the 8.000m peaks with the same format and tags (Scale=1:100.000, Zscale=1, Board size= 180x180).

I like how daylight enhances the relief of the print and the touch feeling it has, the contouring due to the low resolution (0.2mm) is pretty cool though when printing topographies. I'm pretty happy with this print.

About Nanga Parbat (Google it for more ;) )
It's known as one of the most dangerous 8.000m climbs even though it's the 9th highest peak in the world with 8.125m height.
It's rupal face is considered to be the largest in the world and it's what makes this peak so special and worth to make a print out of it.

Got the topography's surface from a GIS software and edited it in Rhino to suit it to the 1:100.000 and 180x180mm format. Also aded the tags with the name, north arrow and graphic scale.

title: Anet A8 Rear frame brace for stepper dampeners

description.text:
A remix of the excellent rear Frame brace by Leo_N allows to mount stepper dampeners onto the bed stepper by offsetting the stepper holder slot 4mm to the right

  • Original stepper holder pin needs to be sanded

  • Original acrylic stepper support can be removed as this is not needed anymore and translates vibrations into the frame

I marked it as thing in progress because i might be inclined to redraw it as a complete drop in replacement, replacing the original mount completely.

SymmetryCAD is an OpenSCAD library for all kinds of geometric symmetry operations. It can be used for enforcing mirror or rotational symmetry on your 3D objects, constructing tilings and tessellations, or for building 3D molecular crystals in OpenSCAD. Functions are available for all 17 possible 2D tilings (wallpaper groups) and all 230 possible 3D tilings (space groups).

Please see the github page for complete instructions and documentation.

This is going to be a planetary gear for my 3d printers extruder. it has the exact dimensions of a nema 17 stepper motor.
This is still a work in progress, the coupling to the motor is still missing.

BOM:
3 x 603 bearing
1 x 604 bearing
2 x 608 bearing
3x M3x10mm screw
3m M3 Nut
8x M2x7mm screw

You will need to print
1 x planetarygear-shaft.stl
1 x planetarygear-rotor-m3.stl
1 x planetarygear-drive-gear.stl
1 x planetarygear-housing-1.stl
1 x planetarygear-housing-2.stl
3 x planetarygear-gear-603.stl

You probably want to turn down your printing speed for the gears and housing-1, as imperfections in printing can cause more friction.

A modified housing for coupling with a nema 17 motor will be added soon (tm).

description.text:

Axis Y1
Axis Y2
Axis Z
Pen Holder

This machine maked for testing GCODE and for my child, she is like draw.

This project include all files: stl + video + grbl09_corexy.rar + photos

UPDATED 28.08.2017

  • ADD kernel_holder_with_springs

GRBL 0.9 Settings Epprom

$0=10 (step pulse, usec)
$1=25 (step idle delay, msec)
$2=0 (step port invert mask:00000000)
$3=0 (dir port invert mask:00000000)
$4=0 (step enable invert, bool)
$5=1 (limit pins invert, bool)
$6=0 (probe pin invert, bool)
$10=3 (status report mask:00000011)
$11=0.010 (junction deviation, mm)
$12=0.002 (arc tolerance, mm)
$13=0 (report inches, bool)
$20=0 (soft limits, bool)
$21=1 (hard limits, bool)
$22=1 (homing cycle, bool)
$23=3 (homing dir invert mask:00000011)
$24=25.000 (homing feed, mm/min)
$25=1000.000 (homing seek, mm/min)
$26=250 (homing debounce, msec)
$27=1.000 (homing pull-off, mm)
$100=100.000 (x, step/mm)
$101=100.000 (y, step/mm)
$102=500.000 (z, step/mm)
$110=2000.000 (x max rate, mm/min)
$111=2000.000 (y max rate, mm/min)
$112=2000.000 (z max rate, mm/min)
$120=10.000 (x accel, mm/sec^2)
$121=10.000 (y accel, mm/sec^2)
$122=10.000 (z accel, mm/sec^2)
$130=293.000 (x max travel, mm)
$131=197.000 (y max travel, mm)
$132=25.000 (z max travel, mm)

GRBL config.h

define HOMING_CYCLE_0 (1<<Z_AXIS)
define HOMING_CYCLE_1 (1<<X_AXIS)
define HOMING_CYCLE_2 (1<<Y_AXIS)

define HOMING_FORCE_SET_ORIGIN

define COREXY

Price

08.2017

  1. Fan 50x50 = 1 USD
  2. Arduino Uno + Shield + Drivers A4948 = 10 USD
  3. Belt 2m = 2 USD
  4. Nema 17 42SHD0001 - 2 * 8 = 16 USD
  5. LM8UU - 8 * x = 5 USD
  6. Roller GT - 2 * 0.75 = 2 USD
  7. 28 BYJ - 48 - 12 В = 2 USD
  8. Rod 415 + Rod 300 = 20 USD
  9. Wires = 5 USD
  10. Other - 10 USD

Total by 08.2017 = 73 USD

description.text:
Here is an experimental, parametric 3D printable Eurorack rail designed to accommodate sliding nuts and potentially threaded strips (haven't tested that out yet). Adjust the parameters to suit your needs and accomodate nuts. Defaults take a standard M3 square nut for the sliding rails and an M6 nut to affix the rail to the bracket. If the nuts are a little tight, you can try "manually" sliding them around. This is designed to work well with my Parametric Eurorack Bracket, so check it out when you get the chace.

I recommend printing with a stiff filament such as a carbon-fiber PLA.

ATTENTION: This is an experimental design provided for fun, and I can make no claims about its safety to you or your expensive modular synthesizer. Some power modules rely on having a metal rail for heat dissipation, something for which a plastic rail is probably inadequate.

A stiff material is preferred. A quality carbon fiber PLA works very well, but most PLA might work reasonably well, if printed dense enough,

title: The Stone Age Swiss Army Knife - an Acheulean Hand Axe!

description.text:
Acheulean (a-shoo-lay-en) hand axes are one of the earliest and most widespread tools in human history. They first emerged almost 2,000,000 years ago and remained a key part of man's tool kit for more than 1,500,000 years. Patterns of wear and tear indicate that hand axes were used for myriad purposes, from gently crushing plant fibers to violently bashing heads - a Stone Age Swiss Army Knife!
This model will let you print your own Acheulean hand axe. It is based on a 3d scan of an actual hand axe from an archaeological site, so it is identical in size and shape to the real thing. Holding it lets you see for yourself how easily it fits in the hand and could be put to work in all kinds of ways. Please be a good citizen though - no head bashing!

The model comes in two versions. One includes an integrated stand, which makes it easier to print and display. If the stand isn't to your liking, cut it off with a utility knife. I finished mine by rubbing it with an acetone-soaked paper towel to take off the rough spots and give it a little luster. The second model includes just the axe, so you can incorporate it into your own projects or print it on its own.

print_settings.Notes:: All parts are meant to be printed easily. All settings may be changed to personal interessts.

description.text:
The whole thing is currently under heavy development and right now not even close to be finished

Since about a year now i follow different sources of DIY DLP/SLA printers and decided to start my very own project.
All parts are designed in a way that they are as easy to be printed on a FDM printer as any possible! Also unlike many approaches i want to use different hardware resources as descripted later on.

What's done so far

  1. Hardware setup
    1.1. Setup OrangePi with Armbian 5.30.
    1.2. Configure Armbian to enable GPIO. WiFi to userlevel roles
    1.3. Get Electron - Electron Quick Start app up and running
    1.4. Setup and configure LCD for UV light projecting
    1.5. Setup hardware (transistor, resistors) to drive 10W UV Lamp 390nm from GPIO
    1.6. Setup Hardware (simple examble setting with capacitor and 1/32 micro steps) to drive DRV8825 stepper driver from GPIO
  2. Softwaredevelopment
    2.1. Express based webserver up and running
    2.2. Communication between projector/webserver/gpio threads
    2.3. Communication with GPIO working
  3. Design and build
    2.1. Design of Z axis parts
    2.2. Build of Z axis parts
    2.3. Design of first draft of OrangePi expansion board (try to keep rPi compatible)
  4. Documentation
    3.1. created this thing on thingiverse :-D

ToDo:

  1. Hardware setup
    1.1. Assemble all parts together as soon, all case parts are done
    1.2. finish and etch OrangePi expansion board
    1.3. some testing about burn time with the hardware setup
  2. Softwaredevelopment
    2.1. A damn lot of stuff
    2.2. Do a nice and usable page for the webserver
    2.3. Finish work on projector (different input file types possibly)
    2.4 Improve installation capabilities (propably this project will be running on rPi's, BananaPi's, whatever machines and types)
    2.5. Upload the whole thing to github.com
    2.6. GCode interpreter planed to reuse slice data from any slicer application (CraftWare, Cura, Slic3r)
    2.7. Extensible configuration options
    2.8. BuiltIn SVG slicing capabilities (most likely will integrate slic3r )
    2.9. Build runner (the actual printing process) into projector thread
  3. Documentation
    3.1. write a BOM
    3.2. Create a source code documentation
    3.3. Create a "HowTo Build"

Github repository

Even though this thing is not even functional yet, i uploaded a repository on github

BOM (Work in Process):

  • 12ea. M3x20 screws
  • 2ea. Smooth rods
  • 1ea. Leadscrew 8mm with nut
  • 1ea. Nema17 motor with driver (recommended DRV8825)
  • 1ea. Motor capacitor (35v 100uF)
  • 1ea. NPN transistor capable of driving the UV LED
  • 1ea. UV LED (10W 390nm in testing right now)
  • 1ea. Computer (Single bord PCs or whatever, shouldn't matter)
  • 1ea. LCD Display (7" 1024x600 in testing right now)
  • 1ea. ATX PSU
  • 2ea. either LM8uu's or Triffid Hunter's Bushings (see below)
  • 1ea. 608z bearing (will propably design a nylon part for this purpose)

a couple of resistors (for the led, as well as pull down transistor)

Printer:

DIY Prusa i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

All parts are meant to be printed easily. All settings may be changed to personal interessts.

Right now everything is designed with Designspark Mechanical
Due to possible different LCDs being use i may do the display holder with OpenSCAD to have it as easy as any possible to change it for any other display.

Other Thingiverse projects being used:
  • loco's Self-centering tapered-thread Z-axis coupling
  • triffid_hunter's Printable LM8UU bushing
    • Special Thanks to Triffid hunter for all his efforts into 3d printing community !

title: Two-piece arms for Mad Cat MKII

description.text: I was having real trouble printing the original arms for the Mad Cat MKII (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44025) without failing. Three consecutive prints failed at exactly the same place; the print head was hitting the print during a non-print move (which there's a lot of due to all the support material). Also, trying to clean out the support material inside the "shield" was near impossible due to the tight spaces. So, I redesigned the arms to be printed as two parts; a "shaft" and the "shield". This also has the benefit of being able to print them in different colors. :) The shaft can be printed without support (but I used a brim); there is a little extra material under the slot that needs to be trimmed away. I had to do a little shaving on the flattened end (making it nice and smooth) to fit into the Mad Cat's body; which is fine, you want it to fit snug. The shield still needs support but it is much less than the original single part. Once printed the shield slides onto the shaft (from the flattened end, up to the tab, which fixes its position on the shaft, and prevents it from rotating.
Note: I printed the original model at 3500%, so the size of these parts is based on that final print size of the original parts.

Print the shafts with a brim (a cylinder on it side mathematically only contacts the print surface at a line); that will give enough surface contact to keep it attached to the print surface, and helps the first few layers at the slotted end.  
The shield needs to be printed with support, of course, since it has 90-degree overhangs.

title: M4-thread Bed Mount for D-Bot Printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a re-implementation of the bed supports for the D-bot printer, beefed up slightly and modified to use an M4 bolt and nut instead of M3, as the stock springs weren't giving the support I expected with a heavy 300x300 aluminum bed (5+lbs with the silicone heat pad and associated hardware).

Note: the bolt spacing is 1mm farther from the aluminum rail than the stock (6mm vs 5mm) because of the larger space needed by the M4 nut, so these aren't an exact drop-in replacement... you'll need to slightly adjust the arms of the bed for the alternate spacing.

title: Self locking Y belt holder for Anet A8

description.text:
This is a self locking belt holder for Anet A8. The belt height is aligned with the pulleys (originally it is 9mm too high). People who have assembled the bed plate holder CORRECTLY by NOT following the Anet A8 assembly instructions, cannot use this because the belt height would already be aligned with the pulleys.

Pros:

  1. Self locking - no screws, adjusts to any belt thickness, no slip
  2. Belt height 9mm below the bed holder - aligned with the pulleys
  3. Belt bottom does not touch the holder (1-2mm clearance)

Cons:

  1. During the self locking operation, a little bit of the tension is released, so a belt tensioner is pretty much a must.

Additional hardware - a spring from pen (see image)

SCAD source is included, you can customize (for example if you have a different spring). The file includes an over-complicated exact GT2 belt model, as an SCAD programming exercise for myself.

title: Raspberry Pi Camera holder for Anet A6

description.text:
Update 2017-09-12
My Raspberry Pi camera has a connector that didn't fit the previous hole, so I removed a section to make room.

OctoPrint can make a timelapse video where images are snapped for each Z axis change. Mounting the camera on some static place gives you a video with jerky motion where the model shifts about - sometimes wildly.

This thing lets you mounting the camera on the Y axis, thus having the camera move along with the build platform and the thing you're printing.

It's specifically designed for the Anet A6 printer, but will work for any printer in the Prusa clone family (and others, I'm sure) where there's a 3mm screw hole with it's center at 4.5mm from a corner.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Supports

As long as you don't have adhesions issues, no extras are required to print. 100% infil for strength in the counter-vibration parts.

Two Different Cameras

There are to my knowledge two different cameras that have different angle of view. For this reason there are two STL files in this thing.

  • Camera version: 1.3. File: AnetA6_PiCamera1.3_holder.stl
  • Camera version: 2.0. File: AnetA6_PiCamera2.0_holder.stl

The holder for the 1.3 camera is longer to allow for the narrower angle of view to get the whole 220 × 220 mm build plate in view.

Mounting

If you print in PLA, this needs to be mounted under the wing nut of the heated bed. If it contacts the heated bed it will melt and bow. The height of the camera holder compensates for some average height of the height adjustment screw setting.

This video shows the holder for camera version 2.0 mounted in the correct place for PLA.

Designed using Fusion 360 with parameters for everything, so it's really easy to do adjustments.

Please let me know if you want any modifications made.

author: skaramicke

description.text: This is a raised sleeve for my "Novo Sublimette" project. You can ceck it out here: http://www.burnheartsynth.com/instruments/electronic/novo-sublimette/
Well, you'd probably need the Novo Sublimette to play this guy, but I put it here for my OpenSCAD coding and maybe to excite some people into the possibilities of 3D printed music interfaces.

Worlds FIRST 3D printed gimbal for Sony NEX 5 cameras! Parts necessary:
  • 2x iPower GBM4008H gimbal motors
  • Martinez (or AlexMos) Gimbal Controller
  • A bearing (OD: 28mm ID: 12mm) to fit inside the left arm
  • some bolts and nuts
  • Shock absorption rubbers (I used Tarot black)
  • Preferably get some 16mm thick (hollow) Carbon Fiber tubes (I included files for tubes too, but they're not as rigid as I'd like)
    • Please see the instructions for detailed construction manual.

You need to print
  • 1x base1.stl (bottom shock absorbtion plate)
  • 1x base2.stl (top shock absorption plate)
  • 4x base3.stl (tube connection clamps)
  • 4x base4.stl (the rings to hang the gimbal on the rails).
  • 1x NEX_5_imu.stl (case for Martinez IMU, I haven't provided any for AlexMos IMU's)
  • 1x NEX_5_gimbal_left_pitch_arm.stl
  • 2x NEX_5_gimbal_right_pitch_arm.stl (one for roll, one for pitch)
  • 1x NEX_5_roll_link.stl (connection between roll motor and roll tube)
  • 1x NEX_5_camera.stl (camera tray)
  • 1x knobM5HEX.stl (knob to tighten camera to the provided tray)
    • Printing
    • NEX_5_roll_link.stl needs lot's of support, but it's fairly easy to clean up as the inside doesn't have to be that beautiful. While you are printing "NEX_5_camera.stl" file, pause the print halfway. There is a channel for the IMU wires to go through. Wait for the channel to appear and put a piece of strong string inside that you can use to pull the four wires for the IMU through. Assembly
    • Please come back later for assembly instructions...

comments.text: Yes I did adapt it to EOS-M. Then I found a better camera Samsung NX500 and it fitted it too. You will need to balance the gimbal with some small counterweights on the roll axis.
comments.author: Henri569

comments.text: Cool! I'll start to print one tomorrow. Do you think would it be a problem if I print all 0.08mm layer and 100 infill (Ultimaker original with heated bed)? I'm used to do solid models if not prototyping.
comments.author: bortek

comments.text: This is totally unnecessary to print on such layer height. You are not printing a jewelry or a thing you going ro show under the microscope. This is just a gimbal :) I would go with 0.2mm layer height and it would still take hours to print all parts.
comments.author: Henri569

comments.text:
Smooth is better :) In fact our Original Ultimaker does pretty crispy / fragile structure if 0.2mm is used. 0.08 is minimum and does very stiff models. After noticing how massive these parts were I ended to print at 50% infill. Largest part takes about 10 hrs.
I tried to print five parts in the weekend and there were some issues with two parts I need to dig a a a little deeper. One failed due geometry failure and one had reinforcements which were not attached to structure properly. I might end up redesigning / converting this partially with Solidworks.
comments.author: bortek

comments.text: I have both STL and Sketchups uploaded in the "thing" so feel free to modify it to your needs.

comments.text: I made one of these but it doesn't seem to be adjustable fr the 18-55 lens. Any Chance to get a V2 of the camera cradle to handle my lens size?
comments.author: VooDooMoN

comments.text: Hi VooDooMon, it's very hard for me to adjust the design to support different lenses as I only have the 16-50. Getting the balance right required a lot of trial and error, so I would need an 18-55 lens to do that. I tried an adjustable version, but that caused too much vibrations, so videos wouldn't look good enough. You could try to edit the Sketchup file I included (the one with TOTAAL in the name). I'm sure you can make it work, it just costs a bit of time and filament :) I hope this helps, if not, let me know!
comments.author: VooDooMoN

comments.text: No worries. I ended up creating a lighter weight camera cradle. It was too much of a pain in the butt to pull the IMU wires through the channel in your design so I just killed the channel entirely. I also adjusted the mount forward (towards the lens) 7mm and up 4mm to match my 18-55. It took 4 test prints to dial in the balance but my Mk V cradle works extremely well. Thank you so much for your design, I can't wait to get it put onto my big quad rig.
comments.author: nwesthoff

comments.text:
Wow VooDooMon! Sounds good.
Be sure to post the file as a remix, and upload photo's in the made section, I'd love to see it :)
For the IMU wires I recommend pausing the print, laying down a strand of wire beforehand and resuming the print after.
You can solder the IMU wires to the first wire, and pull the rest through, that's how I did it anyways, but if you don't mind them going on the outside, just as good!

description.text:
Content (Inhalt)

  1. English
  2. Deutsch

1
Modell Name:
Protecting Cap for Cutter Skalpell

Modell Size:
52mm x 17mm

Modell description and comment:
A safety Cap for the WEDO Cutter Comfortline. Not stylish but robust :P
The provided cap is not bad, but a bit delicate and broke soon.
I recommend to use Skirt/Raft and Brim, since the ground area is small which makes it prone to warping.

2

Modell Name:
Protecting Cap for Cutter Skalpell

Modell Größe:
52mm x 17mm

Modell Beschreibung and Kommentar:
Eine Schutzkappe für das WEGO Hobbymesser. Nicht sehr elegant, aber robust :P
Die mitgelieferte Kappe ist nicht schlecht, aber doch etwas filigran und war schon bald zerbrochen.
Ich empfehle in der Slicer Software 'Skirt' bzw. 'Raft' und 'Brim' (Druckfundamentplatte und Druckrand) zu benutzen, weil die Grundfläche sehr klein ist
und einen stärkeren Halt braucht, um sich beim Drucken nicht vom Druckbett zu lösen.

title: 3.5" Indicator for Flight Simulator
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DBns286NXeo

UPDATE: I upload a new set of gears, with ratio 2.66, (gear without subfix has a ratio of 3.44) easy to print and recomended if you don't need to go over 360º of needle rotation.

Generic Gauge for use in panel of GA Flight Simulators.
It's need 1 servos of 9gr. like SG90, and will be conected to the PC with the flight simulator via OpenCockpits Servo Board, a Arduino or similar system.

It's design in a way that a normal 90º servo movement make more that 300º so in function of the servo and the controller you can get even more that a complete turn of the needle.

You need several 4 M3 screws and nuts for fix the pieces and the instrument to the panel.

I include 3 kinds of bezel and 3 kinds for gauges, so you can make several diferent instrument.
There is also a "ring" and "separator" elements in case you want to mount behind of the panel and want to use a piece of transparent plastic as glass.

For the gauge, in function of the quality of your printer and PLA material, you need to use one option or other.

Also check the instructions for print in the Print Settings part.

For the Attitude Indicator at end of the video check my thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2473812

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

for the back and bezel part you can print like other pieces, but for the gear and other small parts I recomend to use raft, in this way you avoid the deformation of the first layer with the bed (elephant foot).

I also recomend print several gears, axis and needles and select the best one, trim the gears, until you get and good movement.

The small piñon have a hole where you can put a drop of cyanocrilate or a small screw of M2.

The axis can be replaced by any kind of rod of 2mm diameter. if you don't get the needed quality of the print.

title: Creality CR-10 Z Shaft Cover V.1

description.text:
This part replaces the stock Z shaft cover that is useless as the shaft wiggles a lot, with my printer at least, affecting the Z resolution.

This piece should hold the shaft better. I left the top open so it can be greased if needed, although there is a sufficient tolerance between the inner wall and the shaft.

Update 1 Note: This update has the part with a 0.4 mm less inner ring size if the first part does not make the shaft stable enough.

The reason of the variance is that the shaft diameter is not consistent, this is why some reported that the initial part still makes the shaft wobble. My printer shaft diameter for example ranges from 8.4 to 7.8 mm from bottom to top.

If you still have an issue, please let me know.

Printer:

CreatBot DE Plus-3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I highly recommend to print this part with PLA as it has lower shrinkage than ABS, noting that this part does not need to be very strong since it will stay on the top without any pressure or heat.

Also, high resolution is recommenced, 0.1, so the part sits perfectly in place with smooth wall.

Installation

Remove the stock part and simply install this one. It should fit perfectly, unless your print setting includes thick first layer, in which case just sand the bottom edges a bit.

I further added a bit of grease after installation.

title: Détection de fumée => mise à l’arrêt de l’imprimante 3D

description.text:
Détecteur de fumée couplé à mon Anet A8, pour que l’alimentation 220v soit coupé lorsqu’il y a un dégagement de fumée.

Le schéma de principe :

  • le détecteur de fumée génère un signal haut (2.5v en sortie de pin n°7 du microprocesseur).
  • ce signal est inversé (avec des composants type : diode/transistor/condo/résistance)
    pour qu'après ce signal fasse basculer le relais en mode "repos"
    et coupe l'alimentation 220V de l'imprimante.
  • Pour la mise en route : un bouton poussoir viendra shunter les contacts du relais pour faire démarrer l'alimentation.

  • Un autre bouton poussoir serra intégré au détecteur de fumée pour faire office de bouton "OFF". (l'autre solution est d'appuyer sur le bouton test du détecteur de fumée pour couper l'alim mais il y a le bip strident de l'alarme qui retentis donc pas cool. lol)

  • La partie transformation de signal est monté dans le détecteur de fumée, sur une plaque véroboard
  • la partie relais et bouton poussoir "ON" sont installé sous l'alimentation de l'Anet.

Les essais sont concluants : https://youtu.be/LmlGzvOPnBY

Printer:

Anet A8

Notes:

Le fichier STL est pour fixer ma carte relais

author: kaleidoscopeit

description.text:
PetraPrinter: X-Axis (all but the carriage)

I spent a few months on design/build my own printer. Meanwhile I learnt the basics of CAD and 3d-printing itself. The design goals were to build a Prusa-style printer with an enclosure to print high-temp materials like ABS. Although today I would not build this machine this way again, there are still some interesting and somewhat unique solutions that worth sharing. Given these reasons, I'm sharing the files component-by-component instead of the full printer, which has some design flaws.

Whatch the video - [youtube link here]
All OpenSCAD files are available on Github
The PetraPrinter Collection on Thingiverse.

About the parts

Print the idler-holder flat on bed (rotated by 90deg). It's notches are a trick to 100% infill where it really required. This is the only part where sturdiness really matters. I printed it with 5 walls + 30% triangular infill.

remixed_from.title: Parametric Z-axis coupler (stepper and threaded rod coupling)

title: Parametric Coupler for Z-Axis Rod -  Nema 17 Motor

description.text:
All credits and thanks must go to Lorenzo Aspesi, the author of the original script!
I only modified it in order to print on horizontal (instead of vertical) for the following reasons:

  • the screw/nut holes are better defined when printing in this position (at least on my printer, without cooling fan...)
  • the final part has more strength, due to the orientation of the the layers
    I included the .stl files for my particular adapter: 5mm nema17 axis - 8mm threaded rod, with two different heights: 30 and 35mm respectively. The script can also be opened in OpenSCAD and modified to obtain any other adapter variation that is needed.
